title: Cat. 68  Tahitian Landscape (recto), Breton Peasants (verso), 1894
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Tahitian Landscape (recto), Breton Peasants (verso, fig. 68.1)  
1894  
Watercolor monotype from a glass matrix, with touches of gouache (recto); brush and black ink (verso); on cream wove paper laid down on ivory Japanese paper; 217 × 247 mm (recto, image/primary/secondary support)  
Signed recto lower left, in image, in brush and red watercolor: P G O  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Edward McCormick Blair, 2002.238R/V

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Tahitian Landscape, one of several monotypes Gauguin made upon his return to France from Tahiti in 1894, depicts a tranquil and luxuriant landscape. Its subject appears to be the setting itself, saturated with color, especially noticeable in the thick, almost tactile, patches in the grove of trees at the left. As the various visual rhymes between the figures and rock formations seem to suggest, nature and its inhabitants exist in absolute harmony.

At the horizon, to the right, one can see the thatched roof of Gauguin’s hut; a tall, spindly palm tree; and a large mango tree. These elements reoccur in a number of Gauguin’s works, including the wood-block prints Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (fig. 68.2 [cat. 55]) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (fig. 68.3 [cat. 60]), which depict his immediate surroundings in Mataiea, a town in the south of Tahiti. Noticeably absent from Tahitian Landscape is the large Maori idol of Hina, which in the prints appears alongside the group of women dancing in the grove of trees on the left. In a related painting, Nave nave moe (Sacred Spring: Sweet Dreams) (fig. 68.4 [W 512]), the dancers appear in a similar grove of trees in front of a mango tree, and not one but two large statues of the idol tower over them. The absence of these large idols in the Art Institute’s monotype, however, suggests that here religious concerns are secondary.

Rather, the landscape appears to be more idyllic, combining Gauguin’s recollections of Brittany, where the artist lived and worked before his first voyage to Tahiti, with those from his more recent travels. With their long black hair, the women gathered in the grove of trees could be Tahitian, but their traditional, long dresses suggest that they could also be from rural Brittany. Notably, the paper for this monotype appears to have been repurposed from a previous sketch of a Breton scene. The verso bears a faint rendering of two figures in what appears to be European clothing—the female figure is on all fours, in a pose that is strikingly similar to that of the bathing figure kneeling on the red fabric (perhaps a pareu) on the recto.

The work implies unanimity between figure and land—the fine details of a face, a tree branch, or even a specific location seem secondary to the activity of the inhabitants who dance and bathe among the billowing tropical trees. The technique by which Gauguin made this monotype, pulling the impression from an inked piece of glass, lends the image a dreamlike quality. The title for the related painting (Nave nave moe) translates as “delightful drowsiness,” which reinforces the Edenic character of the scene.

Another way in which Tahitian Landscape “makes the familiar strange” is in its restaging of the bather—a typical nineteenth-century French subject—in a Polynesian setting. A woman stands alongside the water’s edge holding a towel, as another bather leans over to wash her hair. Gauguin, like Edgar Degas, employed the monotype to depict the female bather in a decidedly private moment. Fifteen years Degas’s junior, he often visited the older artist’s studio and always admired him. In a sketchbook, Gauguin copied several images of bathers (fig. 68.5) by Degas that he likely saw at an 1888 exhibition (in which he also participated) at Boussod, Valadon et Cie., Paris, a gallery run by Theo van Gogh. The bathing figures on the sketchbook page—Gauguin copied the figure at the center left from Degas’s Kneeling Nude Woman (fig. 68.6), which was on view at the exhibition—appear to be a potential source for the kneeling bather in Tahitian Landscape.

The work also recalls art historical precedents, adding another dimension to the amalgamation of familiar and unfamiliar at play in the image. The standing woman is reminiscent of a figure in Sandro Botticelli’s Birth of Venus (fig. 68.7), the handmaiden who is poised to cover the goddess as her seashell touches shore. In Le Pouldu, Gauguin pinned to his wall a reproduction of Botticelli’s iconic composition; thus he may well have had the handmaiden in mind when executing the Art Institute’s monotype, producing a highly individual take on the time-honored theme of the bathing Venus.  
Mel Becker Solomon

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Ader Picard Tajan at Nouveau Hôtel Drouot, Paris, to Alice Adam Ltd., Chicago, for Edward McCormick Blair (1915–2010), Chicago, Feb. 22, 1984, lot 118.

Given by Edward McCormick Blair to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Washington, D.C., National Gallery of Art, The Art of Paul Gauguin, May 1–July 31, 1988; Art Institute of Chicago, Sept. 17–Dec. 11, 1988, cat. 202 (ill.); Paris, Galeries Nationales du Grand Palais, as Gauguin, Jan. 10–Apr. 20, 1989 (Chicago only).

Bar Harbor, Maine, Ethel H. Blum Gallery, College of the Atlantic, From Paradise to Eden: Gauguin in Tahiti, Aug. 10–Sept. 11, 1999, cat. 11.

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, Sept. 6, 2003–Jan. 11, 2004, cat. 17.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Selected ReferencesRichard R. Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago/New York Graphic Society Books, 1988) pp. 359–60, cat. 202 (ill.).Douglas Druick and Peter Zegers, From Paradise to Eden: Gauguin in Tahiti, exh. cat. (College of the Atlantic, Ethel H. Blum Gallery, 1999), p. 9, cat. 11.Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, exhibition brochure (Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), cat. 17.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed lower left, in image, in brush and red watercolor: P G O

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">For more on the recurrence of the mango tree and Gauguin’s hut, see Noa Noa Scented Sights and cat. 55.

Richard R. Brettell, “Tahitian Landscape (recto); Breton Peasants (verso),” in Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago/New York Graphic Society Books, 1988), p. 359, cat. 202.

For more on Gauguin’s landscapes, see Belinda Thomson, “Landscape and Rural Narrative,” in Gauguin: Maker of Myth, ed. Belinda Thomson, exh. cat. (Tate Publishing, 2010), pp. 110–31.

Bengt Danielsson, “Gauguin’s Tahitian Titles,” Burlington Magazine 109, no. 769 (Apr. 1967), p. 231.

For more on Gauguin’s transformations, see Belinda Thomson, “Landscape and Rural Narrative,” in Gauguin: Maker of Myth, ed. Belinda Thomson, exh. cat. (Tate Publishing, 2010), pp. 92–109.

Degas would eventually purchase six of Gauguin’s monotypes, and an inscription by Degas in the inventory of his art collection (which was sold after his death in 1917) mentions Gauguin’s process, indicating he was interested in his younger colleague’s methods and had discussed them with him: “Water impression, by means of a plate of glass and a paper pressed with a roller, by hand.” See Ann Dumas, “Degas and His Collection,” in The Private Collection of Edgar Degas, exh. cat. (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 1997), p. 65.

George T. M. Shackelford, “The Body Exhibited: Degas’s Nudes in the 1880s,” in Shackelford and Xavier Rey, Degas and the Nude, with contributions by Lucian Freud with Martin Gayford, Anne Roquebert, exh. cat. (MFA Publications, 2012), p. 153.

Gauguin often borrowed motifs from famous European works of art, integrating them into totally unconventional contexts. See for example his wood-block print Te po (The Night) (cat. 52), which references a fresco, thought at the time to be by Giotto, of which he had a photograph. For more examples, see Colta Ives, “Gauguin’s Ports of Call,” in Colta Ives and Susan Alyson Stein, The Lure of the Exotic: Gauguin in New York Collections, with Charlotte Hale and Marjorie Shelley, exh. cat. (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 2002), p. 9.

Alfred Henry Robinson Thornton, The Diary of an Art Student of the Nineties (Sir Isaac Pitman & Sons, 1938), p. 13, cited in Colta Ives, “Gauguin’s Ports of Call,” in Colta Ives and Susan Alyson Stein,The Lure of the Exotic: Gauguin in New York Collections, with Charlotte Hale and Marjorie Shelley, exh. cat. (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 2002), p. 9. Perhaps the trio dancing in the woods in Tahitian Landscape is related to another of Botticelli’s works, Primavera (1477/82; Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence), in which the Graces dance under a canopy of trees.

Alice Adam Ltd., Chicago, invoice addressed to Edward Blair, Sr., Apr. 2, 1984, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. The work was at auction at Ader Picard Tajan, Nouveau Drouot, Paris, Estampes, épreuves provenant de l’ancienne Collection Henri Marillier et de divers amateurs, sale cat. (Mlle D. Rousseau, Feb. 22, 1984), lot 118.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 68 Tahitian Landscape, 1894.

fig. 68.1 Breton Peasants (verso), 1894. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.238V.

fig. 68.2 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude), from the Noa Noa Suite, 1893–94. Printed by Pola Gauguin (Danish, born France, 1883–1961), 1921. Wood-block print in black, on light gray China paper; 205 × 356 mm (image); 271 × 421 mm (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, Joseph Brooks Fair Collection, 1924.1200.

fig. 68.3 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her), 1894/95. Wood-block print in black and hand colored in yellow, green, violet, brown, and red, partly through the use of stencils, on cream Japanese paper; 227 × 520 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, John H. Wrenn Fund, 1946.341.

fig. 68.4 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Nave nave moe (Sacred Spring: Sweet Dreams), 1894. Oil on canvas; 74 × 100 cm (29 1/8 × 39 3/8 in.). State Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg, ГЭ-6510.

fig. 68.5 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Studies of Bathing Women, fol. 3V from the Album Briant. Black crayon on paper; 34.2 × 22.8 cm (13 1/2 × 9 in.). Musée d'Orsay, RF 30273, 6.

fig. 68.6 Edgar Degas (French, 1834–1917). Kneeling Nude Woman, c. 1888. Pastel on paper; 24 × 31 cm (9 7/16 × 12 3/16 in.). Private collection.

fig. 68.7 Sandro Botticelli (Italian, 1445–1510). The Birth of Venus, 1484/86. Tempera on canvas; 172.5 × 278.9 cm (67 15/16 × 109 13/16 in.). Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence.
